figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 56, page 3.

div3.p:
--We received he mail last night either from the South or West, and are consequently without later details of the state of affairs in Tennessee and on the coast.
It is believed, however, that no important movement has taken place in either direction.

div3.head: Congressional.
div3.p: In the Senate, Mr. Barnwell, of South Carolina, from the Committee on Finance, reported a bill fixing the pay of Senators and Representatives at $2,500 per annum, and mileage at 30 cents per mile; the President of the Senate, when acting as such, to receive the pay of the Vice President; and the Speaker of the House to receive double the pay of any other member of that body.--The bill was amended, on motion of Mr. Oldham, of Texas, by striking out $2,500 and inserting $3,000; and further amended by providing for the deduction from the pay the amount of each day's absence without leave, and passed.

The pay of the officers of the Senate was fixed as follows:--Secretary, $2,500 per annum; Assistant Secretary, $1,000; two Clerks, $1,500 each; Sergeant-at-Arms, $2,000; Doorkeeper, $1,500; Assistant Doorkeeper, $1,200--each payable quarterly, in advance, and Page $1 per diem.
A message in waiting from his Excellency, the President, by his Private Secretary, was received, and the Senate resolved itself into Executive session.
In the House of Representatives, yesterday, a resolution was introduced to adjourn the sessions of Congress on the 31st March, and was laid on the table.

Mr. Smith, of Virginia, offered a resolution authorizing the Committee on Postal Affairs to take such action as to modify the law and exclude from the number of military exempts all clerks in post-offices, as well as certain postmasters in charge of minor offices.
The resolution was referred.
Mr. Peter, of Virginia, introduced a bill to continue in office Major and Brigadier Generals of the Provisional Army, which was ordered to be printed, and made the special order for Monday next.
Mr. Peter also offered a bill for the suppression of drunkenness, which was ordered to be printed.
The House had also under consideration the bill for the destruction of cotton, tobacco, and other property, as reported by the Military Committee, which passed by year 71, nays 11.
The bill reads as follows:

q.p: A Bill to Provide for the Destruction of Cotton, Tobacco, and other Property, when the same shall be about to fall into the hands of the enemy.

div3.p: The Congress of the Confederates States do enact, That it shall be the duty of all military commanders in the service of the Confederate States, to destroy all cotton, tobacco, or other property that may be useful to the enemy, if the same cannot be safely removed, whenever, in their judgment, the said cotton, tobacco, and other property is about to fall into the hands of the enemy.

Mr. Miles, from the Committee on Military Affairs, offered a resolution instructing the Committee on the Judiciary to inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill for the compensation of all loyal citizens whose cotton, tobacco, and other property may be destroyed by the military or by themselves, to prevent its falling into the hands of the enemy.
The resolution was agreed to — year 61, noes 19.

Mr. Swan, from the Military Committee, reported a bill for the regulation of passports, as a substitute for a bill referred to the committee.
This bill provides only for the supervision of passports by the Secretary of State, in the case of persons leaving the Confederate States.

Mr. Foots reported back a bill from the Committee on Foreign Affairs for the appointment of Commissioners to attend the World's Fair, in London, on 1st May next:--He asked it be laid on the table and the committee discharged from its further consideration.

Mr. F. also reported a resolution asking information of the President, concerning the presence of certain foreign ships of war in Hampton Boards, and their objects, if not incompatible with the public interest.

div3.head: Opening of Congress.
div3.p:
Yesterday a resolution was adopted in Congress, after some discussion, setting the hour for the opening of Congress at 12 o'clock, one hour later than at present.
The object of this is to give the committees more time for morning work, thereby facilitating the business of the House.

div3.head: General Price.
div3.p:
We are informed that Sterling Price has been promoted to a Major-General, and will be assigned to duty in Missouri.
This is unquestionably a good appointment, for Gen. Price has shown himself a daring and capable office.

div3.head: Gallant conduct at Roanoke Island.
div3.p:
--A volunteer in the Wise Legion, noticing the several accounts of the fight at Roanoke Island, calls our attention to the gallant part performed on that occasion by Capt. Schermerhorn, which has not hitherto received public notice.
He says: "Capt. Schermerhorn commanded an 18 pounder gun, which he stood by and sighted with the utmost coolness and bravery, and laid many a Hessian low during the fight.
His gallantry was praised by officers and men. In the hottest of the engagement, he received in his mouth half of a Minnis hall, which split on his gun, knocking out one of his front teeth."

div3.head: Closing the distilleries.
div3.p:
--Gov. Brown, of Georgia, has issued a proclamation ordering each distiller in that State to desist absolutely from the manufacture of ardent spirits after the 15th day of March, 1862. The Superintendent of the State Road is forbidden to transport any whiskey over that road, and other railroad Superintendents are requested to do likewise.
In case of distillers refusing to obey this order, their stills are to be seized and sent to Rome, Ga., to be manufactured into cannon; and all liquor brought near military encampments is to be emptied upon the ground.

div3.head: The efficient blockade
div3.p: --A large vassal, drawing sixteen feet of water, recently passed out of Charleston harbor, not having the fear of Lincoln or stone fleets in view.

div3.head: Latest Northern and European News.
div3.p: --Northern papers, 61 yesterday, have been received here, and below I send you a condensed report of the principal items or points of news they contain:
Portland, Me., March 4.--The steamship Norwegian has arrived here with Liverpool mail dates to Feb. 20th, and by telegraph from Liverpool to Queenstown to the 31st.
The steamship Tuscarora left Gibraltar on the 18th of February for the Spanish waters at Algeciras.
The Confederate steamer Sumter was still at Gibraltar, waiting for deal.

In the House of Commons the supplementary estimates of expenditures caused by the Trent affair, amounting to 73,000, was agreed to Mr. Bright denounced the policy of the Government, and said that the money was worse than thrown away.
Palmerston said that Bright's opinions were confined to himself.
The gunboats prepared for commission under the Trent difficulty had been directed to be dismantled.

An address to the Emperor of France by the Senate had been read.
The debate commenced on the 20th of February. The address regrets the suffering in France on account of the war in America, and the effect on the trade and manufactories, but agrees with the Emperor that the friendly relations between the two countries renders neutrality incumbent on the part of France.
The French Bourse was lower, and Rentes closed at 95.
The defeat of the Spaniards by the Mexicans is confirmed.

The English Funds at London, were dull, and consols were flat.
Money was in moderate demand at 2½.

St. Louis, March 4. --Columbus has been evacuated by the Confederate troops, and the town has been burned by the rebels.
They have removed the guns to Fort Randolph.
Washington, March 4.--Andy Johnson has been formally appointed military Governor of Tennessee.
United States stocks are quoted at 93.

Liverpool, Feb. 21.--The sales of cotton for four days reach 41,000 bales, of which 20,000 bales were taken by speculators and exporters.
The market closed firm at a slight advance.
The following are the quotations: Fair Orleans, 14½d; Middling Orleans, 13; Fair Mobile, 13½.
No other quotations given.
The stock of Cotton in Liverpool is 479,000 bales, of which 178,000 are American.
At London on the 21st February, the increase in the bullion in the Bank of England was reported to be £148,000.
New York, March 5.--The Herald of this morning says that affairs on the Potomac are quiet.
The late Foreign news states that Earl Russell expresses himself satisfied about the sinking of the stone fleet in the Charleston harbor.
The Herald's Paris correspondent says that the Emperor Napoleon is the enemy of the Union cause, and will show it after he humbles England in Mexico.
American stocks are unchanged in London.
The French troops will not leave Rome.
The difficulty between Austria and Prussia is widening daily.
Washington, March 4.--Gen. Banks's forces occupied Martinsburg on yesterday, without opposition.
It is believed that Gen. "Stone-Wall" Jackson is at Winchester with a strong force.

div3.head: Methodist General Conference postponed.
div3.p: --The Charleston Southern Christian Advocate, of yesterday, contains a letter from Bishop Andrews, postponing the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church South, which was called to meet in New Orleans on the 1st of April.--The letter states that the time and place of meeting will be fixed by a future meeting of the Bishops.

div3.head: Movements of Federal troops.
div3.p: --A very large steamer left Newport News on last evening, loaded with troops, and supposed to be destined to reinforce Gen. Burnside.

div3.head:
Executive Department,
Richmond, Va., March 7, 1862.
div3.p:
all Sheriffs and others collecting State Arms are desired to have the same boxed, marked "Col. O. Dimmock. Richmond, Va.," and forwarded as soon as possible.
The compensation for collecting, and the necessary expanses of transportation to this city, will be paid on the presentation of the receipts of Col. Dimmock.
div3.closer:
Approved,
John Letcher.
City papers copy mh 7--1m

div3.head:
Headq'rs.
Allen Artillery,
opposite Spotswood Hotel.
div3.p: all members of Capt. T. P. Wilkinson's company will report themselves for duty at the rendezvous, on Saturday, at 12 o'clock M.
div3.closer:
By order of the Captain.
John W. Turner,
Lt. Commanding. mh 7--2t

div3.head: Attention, Presidents guard.
div3.p:
Meet at the recruiting office, on Main street, to-day, at 2 o'clock, to be mustered into service.
Every member is required to be present.
div3.closer:
By order of Capt. W. S. Reed.
W. N. Bass, 1st Serg't. mh 7--1t*

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: Private arms that have been received by the State at its Armory, as well as all that may be sent hereafter, will be paid for with in a few days.

div3.head: Special Notice.
div3.p: --All those who have given their names to G. G. Otsy, D. N. Walker, and others of the company, will call to-day (7th) as the Life Insurance Company, opposite the American Hotel, between 10 and 3 o'clock, and sign the roll of the company, and thus avoid the militia draft of Monday next.

div3.head: An able-bodied
div3.p: Five of military duty, can be had by applying to us.
div3.closer:
Clopton & Lyne,
Corner Wall and Franklin streets, mh 7--2* Up stairs.

div4.p:
By Rev. Jas.
E. on the evening of Jan. 2d, 1862, Mr. Jas. Boyden and Miss Mary E. Walton, all of Richmond February 27th, by the same, Mr. Edward Ramsburg and Miss Susan B. Conway, all of Henrico.
On March 6th, at Leigh Street Church, by the Rev. J. B. Solomon, Mr. Joseph A. Smither, of Richmond, and Miss Mary E. Davis, of King William county.
At Halifax, N. C., on the 5th inst., by the Rev. Thos. G. Lowe, Mr. W. Mackey to Miss Clara A. Gatewood, both of this city.
On the morning of the 6th inst., at 20 minutes past 2 o'clock, William Edward, youngest child of Louisa Jane and John Mathews, aged ten months and nine days.

lg.l: Little Willey, thou hast left us,
We thy loss most deeply feel;
But 'tis God that has bereft us,
He can all our sorrows heal,
I take these little lambs, said he,
And lay them in my breast;
Protection they shall find in me,

div4.p: His funeral will take place at his father's residence, this afternoon, at 3 o'clock. The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend, without further notice.
Of consumption, on the th instant, at 9½ o'clock P. M, George N. Robertson, in his 24th year.

His funeral will take place this morning at 11 o'clock, from the residence of his brother, J. R. Robertson, on 8th st., next to City Spring.
His friends, and those of the family, are invited to attend.
On Wednesday evening, Avis, daughter of David N. and Avis M. Walker, aged sixteen months and two weeks.
The funeral will take place from St. Paul's Church this morning, at 11 o'clock.
In Williamsburg, Va., on Sunday evening, about 3 o'clock, Mr. John T. Howell, in the 33d year of his age.

div3.head: Wanted.--to Hire — a negro
div3.p: Blacksmith,
By the month, or for the balance of the year.

Also — A Healper.
Address
div3.closer: "Box 912," Richmond P. O. mh 7--2t*

div3.head: Wanted.--Substitutes
div3.p: for the War

Unnaturalized citizens, over 45 years old, healthy men. None others need apply.
Don't want any others to apply.
Come and know.

div3.head: Wanted.--
div3.p: three Substitutes

are wanted for the war.
Liberal sums given.
Apply at this office at 11 o'clock to-day.

div3.head: Wanted.--twenty
div3.p: Substitutes.
For which a large bounty will be paid.--Apply at Miner & Garber's,
Franklin, between 17th and 18th sts.

div3.head:
Adjutant General's Office,
Richmond Va., Feb. 17, 1861.

div4.p: In pursuance of the provisions of an act of the General Assembly entitled "an act to constitute a corps more effectually to collect the public arms of the State and Confederate States," passed February 12, 1861, the Sheriffs and Sergeants of the several counties and corporations are required forthwith to collect, or cause the public arms of the State to be collected and returned, according to the provisions of the act recited.
No person can acquire the right of property to public arms by purchase, possession or otherwise: therefore, all such claims must be disregarded.

The Governor feels assured that he may, as he does confidently rely upon the patriotism of the officers who are now called upon to render an important public service, under a most pressing public emergency, and doubts not that it will be rendered with promptitude and energy.
div4.closer:
By command.
Wm. H. Richardson, A. G.

div4.p: A copy, of the act sent to each officer.
The arms, if not delivered at this office, must be delivered to Col. Chas. Dimmock, Colonel of Ordnance, but not to any other officer or person, being the property of the State.

Having been authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Battalion or a Regiment of Heavy Artillery, for three years or the war, I should be glad to confer with Captains who have companies not yet mustered into the service, and also those who desire to raise companies.

Volunteers or recruits enlisting for three years will receive a bounty of $50, payable as soon as they are sworn into service and accepted, upon inspection, by a medical officer, together with transportation and subsistence, from the time and place of enlistment, until inspected and mustered.
Twelve months men can re-enlist, singly or by companies for two years or the war, and receive $50 bounty.
To those citizens who have not reported themselves, as required, and who will in a few days be drafted, now is the time, and the last, to serve as volunteers.
Volunteers will be received singly or by companies, from any portion of the Confederacy.
Office under the St. Charles Hotel, Old Dominion Insurance Company, Main street, City Post- Office, Box 877,
I have the promise of Armstrong field pieces; and should it be realized, this regiment will enter the field as Light Artillery.

div3.head: People of Henrico.
div3.p: --I am directed by the Adjutant, General of Virginia to require all persons having muskets, pistols, sabres or rifles, which may at any time have belonged to the State of Virginia or to the Confederate States, to deliver them to me at the County Court-House of Henrico, within twenty days.
No person can acquire right of property in these arms, either by purchase, possession or otherwise.

Any person subject to middle duty, who shall fail to deliver said arms, if in his possession, will at once be drafted into the military service for the war, and those not subject to such duty, will be fined not less than ten dollars.
div3.closer:
Geo. D. Pleasants,
Sheriff of Henrico. mh 6--ts

div3.head: Substitute for the War.
div3.p: A young man, who will not under any circumstances be subject to military duty, can be obtained by any one who will pay liberally, by application to "P. B.," through the Post- Office, stating the amount they are willing to pay. No agent need apply.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: A young man, of a military education, from Alabama, will accept a place as a
div3.closer:
Substitute
To any one willing to pay a good price.
Apply to "H."
Box 872, P. O. Richmond, Va. mh 6--4t*

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillery-men.
div3.p: --All who wish to join the Henrico Light Artillery, which is fully equipped and in service on the Peninsula, will call at the Clerk's Office of Henrico Circuit Court, in the basement of the State Court-House, where they can get information in regard to the bounty of $50, &c.

div3.head:
Adpt and Insp'r Gen. 's Office,
[extract] Richmond, March 5, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders; No. 51:
the regulations concerning Substitutes in the Army, dated October 20, 1861, are hereby revoked.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
Jno. Withers,
Ass't Adj't Gen'l. mh 6--6t

div3.head: Attention!
div3.p: Marylanders.
Persons wishing to join the Maryland Cavalry will call at the office, corner Pearl and Main sts.

div3.head: Attention!
div3.p:
The undersigned propose to raise a company of Light Artillery to be enlisted for the war. We are happy now to announce that we have procured the guns, which will be ready for us, together with all equipments, as soon as our company is mustered into service.
To those who would like to go along with us and share with us the fortunes of this war, we earnestly appeal to come forward now and join us at office.
Besides the bounty of $50, uniforms board and lodgings will be furnished free.
Application may be made at our Recruiting office, on Main, between 7th and 8th streets, or at the store of Johnston & Bransford.

div3.head: A Card.
div3.p:
--The undersigned expects to fill up his company in a few days, with the best material, and those disposed to unite with him had better do so at once.
To be a volunteer is a noble, proud position.
To be a drafted, forced, coerced, militiaman, is almost disgraceful, when it is remembered that we are engaged in the defence of our homes and all we hold most dear in life.
Meetings will be held at my office (Law Building) next Wednesday and Saturday nights, at 8 o'clock.

div3.head:
Headquarters,
Evansport, Va. February 20, 1862.
div3.p:
Special order No. 33.--All furloughs granted to members of Col. Richardson's regiment (47th Virginia) are hereby revoked, and they are required to join their respective companies immediately.
Those detailed on recruiting service are exempt from the above order.
div3.closer:
By order of Gen. French.
F. H. Reynolds,
Assistant Adj't General. fe 24--12t

div4.p: Those wishing to learn the practice of the Sabre, mounted or dismounted exercises, or Lance exercise, can hear of a thorough, practical instructor, who was taught in one of the first military depots in Europe, and who served there for some years as a commissioned officer, by addressing
Cavalry troops in any part of the State will be instructed in the above-named exercises on immediate application of their Captains.

div3.head:
Light Artillery!
battery secured!!!
bounty Fifty Dollars!
div3.p:
The undersigned having secured a splendid battery of field pieces, have authority to raise a Company of Light Artillery, to be mustered into the service of the Provisional Army of Virginia.
for the war. Each man will be entitled to a bounty of $50 upon being mustered in. As an opportunity of enlisting in this arm of the service will not hereafter be of frequent occurrence, those wishing to join will make application at, once at the rendezvous, northwest corner of Cary and 10th streets, where one or more of the undersigned can always be seen.
Those having substitutes will send them in at once, as the ranks are filling rapidly.

div3.head: Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--The present condition of our country seems to us to require the services of all who are capable of bearing arms and in a situation to leave home.
We have therefore obtained from the Secretary of War authority to raise a company of Light Artillery.
and call upon our fellow- citizens to come forward and aid us in getting it up.

We want, if possible, raise a company sufficient to man a battery of six guns, and think this enterprise offers a fine opportunity to all who wish to volunteer, and thus save themselves from a draft in the militia.
Gray uniform, of the Crenshaw Woolen Company Goods, will be furnished free, and the bounty of $50 paid to each man when the company is mustered in.
Rendezvous at the warehouse on the Basin bank, next door to Crenshaw & Co.'s, where one of the undersigned may always be found, and recruits maintained free of all expense.
The traveling expenses of recruits from the country to the city will be paid.

div3.head: Richmond Fayette Artillery.
div3.p:
--Having reorganized and re-enlisted for two years, is desirous of receiving forty additional recruits, to raise the company to the number of one hundred and fifty.
The battery is composed of four brass six-pounder and two rifle guns, and is among the finest in the Confederate army.
The Fayette Artillery is one of the best equipped companies in the service.
A liberal bounty will be given to each recruit.
Only men of respectability, courage, and patriotism, are, however, required.
For further particulars apply to Peyton Johnston, 115 Main street, Richmond, or to the undersigned, at Yorktown.

div3.head:
Headquarters Department of Henrico,
Richmond, Va. March 4, 1862.

list.head: General Orders, no. 3.
list.item: --I By virtue of authority conferred by General Orders, No. 8, Adjutant and Inspector General's Office, March 1st, 1862, Captain A. C. Godwin is appointed Provost Marshal of the city of Richmond and the adjoining and surrounding country for the distance of ten miles.

II.
The Passport Office is continued at its present location, under the charge of the Provost Marshal.

III.
The distillation and distribution of vinous, spirituous, and malt liquors, or other intoxicating beverage, is absolutely prohibited.
This order will be strictly enforced by the Provost Marshal against all persons found distilling, selling, giving away, or in any manner disposing of such beverages.

IV.
All persons, of every degree, except those in the service of the State or Confederate States, having arms in their possession will deliver the same to the Ordnance Department on or before the 5th of March, 1862; otherwise they will be seized and taken possession of by the Provost Marshal.
Arms belonging to the State of Virginia will be delivered to Colonel Dimmock, at the State Arsenal, in this city.
The word arms embraces in its meaning swords, bayonets, rifles, double-barrel shot guns, and pistols of such size as may be useful in the field.
Compensation will be made for private arms delivered up or taken for public use, and Government arms, not in the public service, will be receipted for.

div3.closer:
By order of Brig-Gen. Jno. H. Winder,
Commanding, &c., L. R. Page,
Ass't. Adj't. General. mh 5--1w

div3.head: Attention!.
div3.p:
--The subscribers have authority to raise a company of Light Artillery, to be attached to Major F. J. Boggs's Battalion, to which guns of the most approved kind have been already promised.
As no more flying artillery companies will be received, persons wishing to join this arm of the service will do well to enroll their names at once.
Recent events clearly indicate that Virginia will need the strong arms and brave hearts of all her sons in the impending struggle.
The draft will, within a few days, compel those to take the field who fall to respond to their country's call in this, her hour of peril.
Fifty dollars bounty paid immediately on being mustered in.
div3.closer:
Apply at Bayley & White's office, opposite the Law Building.
Alexander Q. Holladay.
Lieut. 20th Reg. Va., vols.
S. Taylor Martin,
1st Company Howitzers.
Wm. F. G. Garnett, Jr.,
Fayette Artillery.
Richard M. Bolling,
Goochland Troop. fe 26--12t*

div3.head: Artillery
div3.p: service.

The undersigned are authorized to form a Volunteer
Artillery Company,
To serve during the war, and have enough men enrolled to Ensure the Organization, but wish to increase the number to one hundred and twenty-five.
The uniform of the company, for officers and men, will be that prescribed by the army regulations of the Confederate States.

While organized under authority from the Secretary of War, the company will form part of the Virginia quota, and in the draft hereafter to be made each town and county will have credit for each member of this company from such town or county.
Persons volunteering herein will be entitled to the bounty as provided by the Acts of the Confederate Congress.
div3.closer:
Apply, immediately, in person or by letter, to
N. A. Sturdivant,
T. M. Hewitt,
Wm. H. Weisiger,
Chas. R. Darracott. mh 4--6t*

div3.head:
Headqr's Crutchfield battery,
Light Artillery,
Richmond, March 4, 1862.
div3.p: Particular Notice.

Having ceased to receive substitutes in this battery, we are desirous of enlisting 59 intelligent and respectable young gentlemen to fill our ranks.
None but such as will answer the above description will be received.
Substitutes not already in camp, will report themselves at the rendezvous, at the corner of 11th and Cary streets, immediately, otherwise they will be dealt with as deserters, according to law.

div3.head:
Attention!
to arms, young men!!
div3.p: Enroll Promptly.

Having received full authority to raise a
Light Artillery Company,
and having a sufficient number of our best citizens enrolled to guarantee success, persons wishing to join can call at the office of Mr. A. Bolling, or David N. Walker, on Shockoe Slip, where they can see the list and get any information desired.
Persons may be sure of being in a company of the best material and high moral standing, and not be subject to the militia draft of Monday next.

div3.head: Williams Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--Having already enlisted the minimum number required by law for the organization of a Light Artillery Company, and wishing to raise the number to at least one hundred and twenty men, I hereby give notice that I, or some one authorized to act for me, may be found between the hours of 10 A. M. and 12 M., for a few days, at number 44, Main street, under the St. Charles, (also occupied by Mr. Stephen D. Yancey, recruiting for the Magruder Light Artillery) Those wishing to enlist as members of my company, will call as soon as practicable.
$50 bounty will be given I am raising this company under authority of an appointment from the Secretary of War.

div3.head:
Recruits
Richmond Sharp Shooters.
div3.p:
Fifty Recruits are wanted to fill up the ranks of this well-known company to the maximum number.
A bounty of $50 will be paid each recruit, and sustenance commuted until they join the company; pay commences from date of enlistment.
None but good men need apply, as the company heretofore has sustained an enviable reputation.

This company is armed with good Rifles, and has seen as much active service as any company in the army.
Application to be made to the undersigned at Star Exchange, Bank street, or to Corporal W. J. Wingfield.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The undersigned are authorized by the Secretary of War to raise an Artillery Company, which is partially formed.
Persons desiring to join the same will apply at the office of Bayly & White, corner of 12th and Franklin streets, Richmond; Col. Wm. R. Winn, Hanover; or to Major John S Thompson, Ashland.
A bonus of fifty dollars given to each volunteer, and uniforms furnished free.
div3.closer:
Samuel T. Bayly,
Capt. Co "A," 20th Reg. Va. Vols.
Wm. R. Winn,
Col 74th Reg. Va. Militia.
N. B.--None but persons of good character need apply. mh 5--6t*

div3.head: Substitutes.
div3.p:
Any person who wishes a Substitute will find one by inquiring at the Dispatch office, or at Mrs. Eddins's Boarding-House.
None need apply unless he is ready to pay one thousand dollars in gold, or its equivalent.
The person who offers is a soldier more capable to command than one- half of the army.

div3.head: State arms.
div3.p:
By an act of the General Assembly, passed February 12, 1862, it is made my duty in part to collect all the muskets, pistols, rifles, and sabres belonging to the State of Virginia from persons in the city not in the military service.
I therefore request all persons having any such arms in their possession to leave them at my office, at the City Hall, within the next twenty days, as the penalty is heavy for a failure to do so.

div3.head:
Adj't and Insp'r Gen's Office,
Richmond, Feb, 26, 1862.
div3.p:
Special Orders No. 46--Xiv. Hereafter no reward will be paid for the apprehension of deserters.
[Extract.]
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
John Withers, Ass't Adj't Gen'l. fe 28--1w]

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --As my term of service will expire on the 21st of April, I wish to raise a Volunteer Company, on or before that time, to be mustered into service for the war, or two years. Those who wish to join, can do so by calling on Capt. D. W. Saunders, at the old stand of George Timberlake & Son, on Brook Avenue.
div3.closer:
David B. Jones,
Company "F," of Richmond. fe 22--18t*

div3.head:
Attention, Citizen soldiers.
Fifty or Sixty
able-bodied men, wanted.
div3.p:
The undersigned having had considerable military experience, had acceptably attached to the Wise Legion as Captain of Artillery, desires to organize another similar company for immediate service in the Confederate States service.
Each man will be paid Fifty Dollars bounty money when enlisted, and have his uniform furnished.
Now is the time to rally for the defence of our country against the base Yankee invaders.

Headquarters on 10th between Main and Cary.
Streets.

div3.head: University Volunteers.
div3.p: --The undersigned, formerly Captain and First Lieutenant of this company, propose raising another company for the war.
Old members of the company, and others desiring to unite with us, are requested to come forward immediately and aid us in filling up the company.
Fifty Dollars bounty and clothing furnished.
div3.closer:
Jas. P. Crane.
Richmond.
Jas. Dinwiddie.
Greenwood Depot, Albemarle co., Va. fe 28--1w*

div4.p:
--And Uniforms furnished.--The undersigned, having been duly authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Company of Heavy Artillery, to man the batteries at Yorktown, want a few more men to complete the Company.
For further particulars, apply to Sergeant James McDonald, 12th street, opposite the Enquirer office.
Those persons who are desirous of enlisting in my company, will also find a Rendezvous on Franklin st., opposite Messrs. Dickinson, Hill & Co., where an officer may be found to enroll them.

Having been detailed to recruit for the First Regiment Virginia Volunteers, (now stationed at Centreville,) a bounty of Fifty Dollars, uniform and subsistence, will be given to all able-bodied young men who may enlist in this, the oldest volunteer regiment in the Confederate States.
For further particulars apply at the recruiting station, No. 3, 10th street, between Main and Cary streets.
Lieutenant and Recruiting Officer,
P. S.--Two new companies will be received, as there are at present but eight in the regiment.

div3.head: A Card.
div3.p:
--Having received authority from the Secretary of War to raise a Company of Infantry, those who may desire to join it will please report themselves at my office, in the Law Building, between the hours of 11 and 12 A. M. Meetings will be held also at the same place on each Saturday and Wednesday night, till the company shall have been fully organized.
Amount of $50; together with subsistence and clothing, will be furnished each recruit when he enrolls his name.

div3.head: Runaway.$100 Reward.
div3.p:
If found without $50 if found within this State.
Runaway in November last, Jesse, a man about 24 years old. He is about 5 feet 10 or 11 inches in height, very slim and delicate-looking, has been brought up as a dining room servant, has sprightly manners, is of a gingerbread color, has one sprained and limps slightly, has one of his thumbs a great deal enlarged from a whitlow and has rather red eyes.
The above reward will be paid If he be delivered to Mr. Ed. D. Eacho, or lodged in jail in Richmond.

div3.head: $25 Reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed from the 4th Regiment Virginia Cavalry, at Camp Ewell, near Manassas, a bay Mare, six years old, star in forehead, thick set, in good order, bushy mane and tail, and one hind leg a little larger than the other.
Raise her mane and you will see where it has been trimmed underneath.
I will give the above reward to any one returning the above-described mare to me, or for any information which will enable me to get her.
div3.closer:
Edmond Rossieux,
Lieut. Co, I, 4th Va. Cav. mh 5--12t*

div3.head: Ranaway.
div3.p:
--$10 Reward.--From my house, on the 4th of February, Andrew, slave belonging to the estate of Mrs. Nancy D. Priddy.
He is about 5 feet 8 inches high, and black.
I will give the above reward for his apprehension.

div3.head: Ranaway--$200 Reward.
div3.p:
--From the residence of the subscriber, on the 30th Nov., negro boy Isaac, about 30 years old, 5½ feet high, ginger-bread complexion, of pleasant and polite manners, hair short and nappy, and is left-handed.
I will give the above reward for the apprehension and delivery of said boy in the jail at Orange C. H.

This negro ran off in consequence of having committed a most and unprovoked murder upon the person of my overseer, and it behooves the community at large to be on the look-out for this criminal.
He may be in the vicinity of Fredericksburg, where he has acquaintances.

div3.head: $50 Reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on Friday night last, two negro men, Isaiah and Charles.
Isaiah is about 22 years of age, black, about 5 feet 8 inches tall, quick spoken and quite intelligent.
Charles is about 45 years old, dark brown complexion, 5 feet 8 or 9 inches high, and not very intelligent.
They were both originally from North Carolina, and may be endeavoring to make their way back to that State.
I will give a reward of $25 for the arrest and return of either, or $50 for both.
div3.closer:
Robert H. Styll.
Richmond city. mh 3--6t*

div3.head: Runaway.
div3.p: --$20 Reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery to me, corner of 5th and Cary sts. of my man Henry sometimes calls himself John Henry Evans, who absconded about the 2d inst. He is about 21 years old, black; no scars or marks recollected; very spare made; about 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high; a blacksmith by trade; a very good barber and dining-room servant; has a wife, I am told, at Mr. Chas. Friend's, in Chesterfield, where he may have gone, or he may be still in the city.

div3.head: Ranaway.
div3.p:
--$100 Reward if found without, $50 if found within this State.
Runaway in November last, Jim, a man about 24 years old. He is about 5 feet 10 or 11 inches high, very thin and delicate looking; has been brought up as a dining-room servant; has sprightly manners; is of a ginger- bread color; has one ankle sprained and limps slightly; has one of his thumbs a good deal enlarged from a whitlow, and has rather red eyes.
The above reward will be paid if he be delivered to Mr. E. D. Eacho, or lodged in a Richmond jail.

$50 Reward for my Servants, John and black well.
John is about twenty-three years old and a carpenter by trade; black and not stout.
He left my residence at the corner of Clay and 10th streets, Sunday morning, the 23d instant.
I have no doubt he is in the employment of some of the companies as a free man, in or near the city, or he may have left it. Black-well left my farm, in the county of Chesterfield, ten miles above Richmond.
He is 15 years old; a bright mulatto; he has large, full eyes, thick underlips, spare made knees, and ankles inclined inward.
He left on the 13th instant; he is a house-servant.
I will give twenty-five for one, or fifty for the two, delivered to me in Richmond at my residence, corner Clay and 10th streets, or in any jail, so that I can get them.

div3.head: Runaway.
div3.p: --A negro boy by the name of Floyd, had been staying with his young master at Evansport, and was taken sick and started home with a man by the name of Dr. H. E. Herst, and the train left him at Burkesville, Va. The said boy is about 35 years of age, dark complexion, about 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high.--His general weight is about 150 pounds. Any person taking up the said boy, will have him confined in some safe jail, and I will pay all charges for his delivery to me.
div3.closer:
J. W. Alsobrooks,
Mill Town, Alabama. fe 17--1m*

div3.head: Ranaway--$25 Reward.
div3.p:
--A negro man named Gilbert, aged between 40 and 50 years. His color is black; whiskers grey, under the chin.
He is about six feet high; black hair.
His clothing is a black coat and plaid summer pants.
I bought him at Dickinson &Hill's auction room last Tuesday.
He was brought here by a gentleman named Thos. G. Neal, of North Carolina.
He left my premises Saturday afternoon, between 2 and 3 o'clock. The above reward will be paid by
div3.closer:
M. A. Myers, 66 Main street,
Richmond, Va.
Or lodged in some convenient Jail. fe 3--1m*
